statement.text: Surgical intervention in Takayasu arteritis should be performed during disease quiescence whenever possible, as active inflammation at the time of surgery increases complication rates including anastomotic failure and restenosis.

explanation.intuition: Operating on inflamed, swollen arteries is like sewing into wet tissue paper - sutures tear through and repairs fail. When the inflammation is controlled (quiescent phase), the arteries are stronger and heal better.
explanation.key_insight: Disease activity assessment before surgery is critical. Markers include ESR, CRP, and imaging (PET-CT). Elective procedures should wait for quiescence. Emergency intervention may be necessary despite active disease.
explanation.technical_details: Quiescence criteria: normal ESR/CRP, no systemic symptoms, stable imaging. Imaging: PET-CT can assess metabolic activity. Active disease risks: anastomotic aneurysm (15% vs 5%), restenosis (30% vs 10%), suture line dehiscence. Surgical considerations: bypass preferred over endarterectomy (avoid inflamed vessels), extra-anatomic routes may be needed, autologous conduit preferred. Exception: critical limb-threatening or organ-threatening ischemia may require urgent intervention despite active disease.

clinical_features.exceptions: Emergency intervention for critical ischemia despite active disease

clinical_pearls: Operate during quiescence - active inflammation triples complication rates
Check ESR/CRP and consider PET-CT before elective surgery
Bypass preferred over endarterectomy to avoid inflamed arterial walls
